news_summary: Innovative advancements in magnetic materials, DNA-based nanotechnology, and collective intelligence in robotics are poised to revolutionize the future of electronics and technology.
news_summary_fr: Les avancées novatrices dans le domaine des matériaux magnétiques, de la nanotechnologie basée sur l'ADN et de l'intelligence collective en robotique sont sur le point de révolutionner l'avenir de l'électronique et de la technologie.
news_summary_es: Los avances innovadores en materiales magnéticos, nanotecnología basada en el ADN e inteligencia colectiva en robótica están a punto de revolucionar el futuro de la electrónica y la tecnología.

articles.title: This tiny metal switches magnetism without magnets — and could power the future of electronics
articles.summary: Researchers at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities have made a promising breakthrough in memory technology by using a nickel-tungsten alloy called Ni₄W. This material shows powerful magnetic control properties that can significantly reduce energy use in electronic devices. Unlike conventional materials, Ni₄W allows for "field-free" switching—meaning it can flip magnetic states without external magnets—paving the way for faster, more efficient computer memory and logic devices. It's also cheap to produce, making it ideal for widespread use in gadgets from phones to data centers.
articles.content:
Research from the University of Minnesota Twin Cities gives new insight into a material that could make computer memory faster and more energy-efficient.

The study was recently published in Advanced Materials, a peer-reviewed scientific journal. The researchers also have a patent on the technology.

As technology continues to grow, so does the demand for emerging memory technology. Researchers are looking for alternatives and complements to existing memory solutions that can perform at high levels with low energy consumption to increase the functionality of everyday technology.

In this new research, the team demonstrated a more efficient way to control magnetization in tiny electronic devices using a material called Ni₄W-a combination of nickel and tungsten. The team found that this low-symmetry material produces powerful spin-orbit torque (SOT) -- a key mechanism for manipulating magnetism in next-generation memory and logic technologies.

"Ni₄W reduces power usage for writing data, potentially cutting energy use in electronics significantly," said Jian-Ping Wang, a senior author on the paper and a Distinguished McKnight Professor and Robert F. Hartmann Chair in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities.

This technology could help reduce the electricity consumption of devices like smartphones and data centers making future electronics both smarter and more sustainable.

"Unlike conventional materials, Ni₄W can generate spin currents in multiple directions, enabling 'field-free' switching of magnetic states without the need for external magnetic fields. We observed high SOT efficiency with multi-direction in Ni₄W both on its own and when layered with tungsten, pointing to its strong potential for use in low-power, high-speed spintronic devices." said Yifei Yang, a fifth-year Ph.D. student in Wang's group and a co-first author on the paper.

Ni₄W is made from common metals and can be manufactured using standard industrial processes. The low-cost material makes it very attractive to industry partners and soon could be implemented into technology we use everyday like smart watches, phones, and more.

"We are very excited to see that our calculations confirmed the choice of the material and the SOT experimental observation," said Seungjun Lee, a postdoctoral fellow in ECE and the co-first author on the paper.

The next steps are to grow these materials into a device that is even smaller from their previous work.

In addition to Wang, Yang and Lee, the ECE team included Paul Palmberg Professor Tony Low, another senior author on the paper, Yu-Chia Chen, Qi Jia, Brahmudutta Dixit, Duarte Sousa, Yihong Fan, Yu-Han Huang, Deyuan Lyu and Onri Jay Benally. This work was done with Michael Odlyzko, Javier Garcia-Barriocanal, Guichuan Yu and Greg Haugstad from the University of Minnesota Characterization Facility, along with Zach Cresswell and Shuang Liang from the Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science.

This work was supported by SMART (Spintronic Materials for Advanced InforRmation Technologies), a world-leading research center that brings together experts from across the nation to develop technologies for spin-based computing and memory systems. SMART was one of the seven centers of nCORE, a Semiconductor Research Corporation program sponsored by the National Institute of Standards and Technology. This work is being supported by the Global Research Collaboration Logic and Memory program. This study was done in collaboration with the University of Minnesota Characterization Facility and the Minnesota Nano Center.
articles.reasoning: This article describes a significant scientific breakthrough in memory technology that promises faster, more energy-efficient, and cost-effective electronics. It highlights potential environmental benefits through reduced energy consumption and the use of common, low-cost materials, making it accessible for widespread use. Such advances are likely to inspire hope for smarter, sustainable technology in everyday life.
articles.personality_title: New metal alloy flips magnetism without magnets, promising greener electronics
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
As our devices get smarter and faster, they need better memory that doesn’t drain energy. Traditional memory tech relies on magnets to work, but this uses a lot of power and can slow things down.

**What happened**
Researchers at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities discovered that a metal mix called Ni₄W—a nickel-tungsten alloy—can switch its magnetic state without needing external magnets. This 'field-free' switching means the material can change how it stores information using less energy and more speed. Plus, Ni₄W is cheap and easy to make.

**Impact**
This breakthrough could lead to memory chips that save electricity and run faster, helping gadgets like phones and computers be more efficient. Because Ni₄W is affordable, it could soon be used widely, from small devices to big data centers, reducing overall energy use and environmental impact.

**What's next step**
The research team plans to develop practical devices using Ni₄W and work on bringing this technology from the lab to everyday electronics. They have also secured a patent, paving the way for future innovations and commercial use.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A simple metal alloy that flips magnetism without magnets offers a promising path to faster, greener electronics for everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouvel alliage métallique change de magnétisme sans aimants, promettant des appareils plus écologiques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Alors que nos appareils deviennent plus intelligents et rapides, ils ont besoin d'une meilleure mémoire qui consomme moins d'énergie. La technologie mémoire traditionnelle utilise des aimants, ce qui demande beaucoup d'énergie et peut ralentir le fonctionnement.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs de l'Université du Minnesota Twin Cities ont découvert qu'un alliage métallique appelé Ni₄W, composé de nickel et tungstène, peut changer son état magnétique sans aimants externes. Ce changement sans champ magnétique permet de stocker l'information en consommant moins d'énergie et plus rapidement. De plus, Ni₄W est peu coûteux et facile à produire.

**Impact**
Cette avancée pourrait permettre des puces mémoire plus économes en électricité et plus rapides, rendant les appareils comme les téléphones et ordinateurs plus efficaces. Comme Ni₄W est abordable, il pourrait être largement utilisé, des petits appareils aux centres de données, réduisant ainsi la consommation d'énergie et l'impact environnemental.

**Prochaine étape**
L'équipe de recherche prévoit de développer des dispositifs pratiques avec Ni₄W et de faire passer cette technologie du laboratoire aux appareils du quotidien. Ils ont aussi obtenu un brevet, ouvrant la voie à des innovations futures et à une utilisation commerciale.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Un alliage métallique simple qui change de magnétisme sans aimants ouvre la voie à des appareils électroniques plus rapides et plus écologiques pour tous.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva aleación metálica cambia el magnetismo sin imanes, prometiendo dispositivos más ecológicos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
A medida que nuestros dispositivos se vuelven más inteligentes y rápidos, necesitan memorias mejores que consuman menos energía. La tecnología de memoria tradicional usa imanes, pero esto consume mucha energía y puede ralentizar el funcionamiento.

**Qué sucedió**
Investigadores de la Universidad de Minnesota Twin Cities descubrieron que una mezcla metálica llamada Ni₄W, una aleación de níquel y tungsteno, puede cambiar su estado magnético sin necesidad de imanes externos. Este cambio sin campo magnético permite almacenar información con menos energía y mayor rapidez. Además, Ni₄W es barato y fácil de producir.

**Impacto**
Este avance podría llevar a chips de memoria que ahorran electricidad y funcionan más rápido, ayudando a que dispositivos como teléfonos y computadoras sean más eficientes. Como Ni₄W es accesible, pronto podría usarse ampliamente, desde dispositivos pequeños hasta grandes centros de datos, reduciendo el consumo de energía y el impacto ambiental.

**Próximo paso**
El equipo de investigación planea desarrollar dispositivos prácticos usando Ni₄W y llevar esta tecnología del laboratorio a la electrónica diaria. También han obtenido una patente, allanando el camino para futuras innovaciones y uso comercial.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Una aleación metálica sencilla que cambia el magnetismo sin imanes ofrece un camino prometedor hacia electrónicos más rápidos y ecológicos para todos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, intricately patterned metallic lattice combining nickel and tungsten atoms, illustrated as intertwined silver and warm bronze strands emitting soft pulses of light in multiple directions, symbolizing dynamic magnetic switching and energy flow, set against a calm, neutral background to evoke innovation and sustainable technology.

articles.title: Scientists twist DNA into self-building nanostructures that could transform technology
articles.summary: Scientists have used DNA's self-assembling properties to engineer intricate moiré superlattices at the nanometer scale—structures that twist and layer like never before. With clever molecular “blueprints,” they’ve created customizable lattices featuring patterns such as honeycombs and squares, all with remarkable precision. These new architectures are more than just scientific art—they open doors to revolutionizing how we control light, sound, electrons, and even spin in next-gen materials.
articles.content:
Researchers are creating new moiré materials at the nanometer scale using advanced DNA nanotechnology: DNA moiré superlattices form when two periodic DNA lattices are overlaid with a slight rotational twist or positional offset. This creates a new, larger interference pattern with completely different physical properties. A new approach developed by researchers at the University of Stuttgart and the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research not only facilitates the complex construction of these superlattices; it also unlocks entirely new design possibilities at the nanoscale. The study has been published in the journal Nature Nanotechnology.

Moiré superlattices have become central to modern condensed matter and photonic research. However, realizing such structures typically involves delicate and laborious fabrication steps, including precise alignment and transfer of pre-fabricated layers under highly controlled conditions. "Our approach bypasses traditional constraints of creating moiré superlattices," says Prof. Laura Na Liu, director of the 2nd Physics Institute at the University of Stuttgart.

New paradigm for the construction of moiré superlattices

"Unlike conventional methods that rely on mechanical stacking and twisting of two-dimensional materials, our platform leverages a bottom-up assembly process," explains Laura Na Liu. The assembly process refers to the linking of individual DNA strands to form larger, ordered structures. It is based on self-organization: The DNA strands join together without external intervention, solely through molecular interactions. The Stuttgart research team is taking advantage of this special feature. "We encode the geometric parameters of the superlattice -- such as rotation angle, sublattice spacing, and lattice symmetry -- directly into the molecular design of the initial structure, known as the nucleation seed. We then allow the entire architecture to self-assemble with nanometer precision." The seed acts as a structural blueprint, directing the hierarchical growth of 2D DNA lattices into precisely twisted bilayers or trilayers, all achieved within a single solution-phase assembly step.

Exploring Uncharted Territory: Moiré Structures on the Intermediate Nanometer Scale

While moiré superlattices have been widely explored at the atomic (angstrom) and photonic (submicron) scales, the intermediate nanometer regime, where both molecular programmability and material functionality converge, has remained largely inaccessible. The Stuttgart researchers have closed this gap with their current study. The team combines two powerful DNA nanotechniques: DNA origami and single-stranded tile (SST) assembly.

Using this hybrid strategy, the researchers constructed micrometer-scale superlattices with unit cell dimensions as small as 2.2 nanometers, featuring tunable twist angles and various lattice symmetries, including square, kagome, and honeycomb. They also demonstrated gradient moiré superlattices, in which the twist angle and hence moiré periodicity varies continuously across the structure. "These superlattices reveal well-defined moiré patterns under transmission electron microscopy, with observed twist angles closely matching those encoded in the DNA origami seed," notes co-author Prof. Peter A. van Aken from the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research.

The study also introduces a new growth process for moiré superlattices. The process is initiated by spatially defined capture strands on the DNA seed that act as molecular 'hooks' to precisely bind SSTs and direct their interlayer alignment. This enables the controlled formation of twisted bilayers or trilayers with accurately aligned SST sublattices.

Broad implications across molecular engineering, nanophotonics, spintronics, and materials science

Their high spatial resolution, precise addressability, and programmable symmetry endow the new moiré superlattices with significant potential for diverse applications in research and technology. For example, they are ideal scaffolds for nanoscale components -- such as fluorescent molecules, metallic nanoparticles or semiconductors in customized 2D and 3D architectures.

When chemically transformed into rigid frameworks, these lattices could be repurposed as phononic crystals or mechanical metamaterials with tunable vibrational responses. Their spatial gradient design also opens avenues for transformation optics and gradient-index photonic devices, where moiré periodicity could steer light or sound along controlled trajectories.

One particularly promising application lies in spin-selective electron transport. DNA has been shown to act as a spin filter, and these well-ordered superlattices with defined moiré symmetries could serve as a platform to explore topological spin transport phenomena in a highly programmable setting.

"This is not about mimicking quantum materials," says Laura Na Liu. "It's about expanding the design space and making it possible to build new types of structured matter from the bottom up, with geometric control embedded directly into the molecules."
articles.reasoning: This article describes a significant scientific breakthrough in DNA nanotechnology that enables the creation of customizable nanostructures with potential to revolutionize multiple fields such as photonics, spintronics, and materials science. The innovation opens new possibilities for advanced materials and technologies, which is hopeful and inspiring for future technological progress.
articles.personality_title: Scientists engineer DNA to build tiny, twisting nanostructures with big potential
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long admired DNA for its ability to self-assemble—meaning it can naturally join together into specific shapes. Researchers wanted to harness this to create tiny, complex structures that could change how we design new materials.

**What happened**
A team at the University of Stuttgart and the Max Planck Institute developed a clever way to twist and layer DNA lattices, creating what are called moiré superlattices at the nanometer scale. By slightly rotating or shifting two grids of DNA, they made new, larger patterns like honeycombs and squares with incredible precision.

**Impact**
These tiny, customizable structures aren’t just pretty—they have unique physical properties that could revolutionize how we control light, sound, and electronic behaviors. This means potential breakthroughs in advanced technologies such as photonics (using light), spintronics (using electron spin), and new materials that behave in exciting ways.

**What's next step**
The researchers aim to explore practical applications of these DNA-built materials in real-world devices. They’ll continue refining the designs and studying how these new structures can be used to improve technology in electronics, sensors, and beyond.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By twisting DNA into tiny, self-building patterns, scientists are opening doors to smarter, more advanced materials that could reshape future technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques façonnent l’ADN pour créer de minuscules nanostructures torsadées aux grands potentiels
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques admirent depuis longtemps la capacité de l’ADN à s’auto-assembler, c’est-à-dire à se joindre naturellement pour former des formes spécifiques. Les chercheurs ont voulu utiliser cette propriété pour créer de petites structures complexes pouvant changer la conception des nouveaux matériaux.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une équipe de l’Université de Stuttgart et de l’Institut Max Planck a développé une méthode ingénieuse pour tordre et superposer des réseaux d’ADN, créant ce qu’on appelle des super-réseaux de moiré à l’échelle du nanomètre. En faisant légèrement pivoter ou décaler deux grilles d’ADN, ils ont créé de nouveaux motifs plus grands comme des nids d’abeilles et des carrés avec une précision incroyable.

**Impact**
Ces structures minuscules et personnalisables ne sont pas seulement esthétiques : elles possèdent des propriétés physiques uniques qui pourraient révolutionner la manière dont nous contrôlons la lumière, le son et le comportement des électrons. Cela ouvre la voie à des avancées dans des technologies avancées comme la photonique (utilisation de la lumière), la spintronique (utilisation du spin des électrons) et de nouveaux matériaux aux comportements innovants.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs souhaitent explorer les applications pratiques de ces matériaux fabriqués en ADN dans des dispositifs réels. Ils continueront à affiner leurs modèles et à étudier comment ces nouvelles structures peuvent améliorer les technologies dans l’électronique, les capteurs et plus encore.

**Une phrase clé**
En torsadant l’ADN en petits motifs auto-construits, les scientifiques ouvrent la voie à des matériaux plus intelligents et avancés qui pourraient transformer la technologie de demain.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos diseñan ADN para crear minúsculas nanostructuras retorcidas con gran potencial
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han admirado durante mucho tiempo la capacidad del ADN para autoensamblarse, lo que significa que puede unirse de forma natural en formas específicas. Los investigadores querían aprovechar esto para crear estructuras diminutas y complejas que pudieran cambiar la forma en que diseñamos nuevos materiales.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de la Universidad de Stuttgart y el Instituto Max Planck desarrolló una forma ingeniosa de torcer y superponer redes de ADN, creando lo que llaman superredes de moiré a escala nanométrica. Al rotar o desplazar ligeramente dos rejillas de ADN, hicieron nuevos patrones más grandes como panales y cuadrados con una precisión increíble.

**Impacto**
Estas estructuras diminutas y personalizables no solo son bonitas, sino que tienen propiedades físicas únicas que podrían revolucionar cómo controlamos la luz, el sonido y el comportamiento electrónico. Esto significa posibles avances en tecnologías avanzadas como la fotónica (uso de la luz), la espintrónica (uso del giro del electrón) y nuevos materiales con comportamientos emocionantes.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean explorar aplicaciones prácticas de estos materiales hechos de ADN en dispositivos del mundo real. Continuarán perfeccionando los diseños y estudiando cómo estas nuevas estructuras pueden usarse para mejorar la tecnología en electrónica, sensores y más.

**Una frase clave**
Al torcer el ADN en patrones diminutos que se construyen solos, los científicos abren puertas a materiales más inteligentes y avanzados que podrían transformar la tecnología futura.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of intricately interwoven, twisting double-helix DNA strands forming layered, geometric lattices with subtle moiré patterns glowing softly at the nanometer scale, surrounded by delicate molecular "hooks" guiding the assembly, set against a simple, softly gradient background to evoke controlled, self-building nanostructures with harmonious symmetry.

articles.title: Robots demonstrate principles of collective intelligence
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02269-4Lessons from developmental biology can be used to guide the behaviour of robot swarms.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses how principles from developmental biology are being applied to guide robot swarm behavior, representing a scientific and technological breakthrough that could lead to improved collective intelligence in robotics. This advancement has potential positive implications for various fields, showcasing innovation and progress.
articles.personality_title: Robots learn teamwork from biology to work smarter together
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have been studying how robots can work together in groups, known as swarms, to solve problems more efficiently. They found inspiration in developmental biology, the study of how living things grow and develop, to improve robot teamwork.

**What happened**
Researchers applied lessons from how cells communicate and organize during growth to guide robot swarms. By mimicking these natural processes, robots were able to coordinate their actions better and adapt to changing situations without central control.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means robot teams can now work more effectively as a group, showing smarter collective behavior. It opens up new possibilities in fields like search and rescue, agriculture, or environmental monitoring where coordinated robot groups can be very useful.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to refine these biological principles further and test robot swarms in real-world situations. The goal is to create robotic systems that can self-organize and tackle complex tasks alongside humans.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By learning from nature’s teamwork strategies, robots are becoming smarter collaborators, ready to help us in many important ways.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les robots s’inspirent de la biologie pour mieux travailler ensemble
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques étudient comment les robots peuvent travailler en groupe, appelés essaims, pour résoudre des problèmes plus efficacement. Ils se sont inspirés de la biologie du développement, l’étude de la croissance des êtres vivants, pour améliorer la coopération des robots.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs ont appliqué des leçons sur la communication et l’organisation des cellules pendant leur croissance pour guider des essaims de robots. En imitant ces processus naturels, les robots ont mieux coordonné leurs actions et se sont adaptés sans contrôle central.

**Impact**
Cette avancée signifie que les équipes de robots peuvent maintenant fonctionner plus efficacement en groupe, montrant un comportement collectif plus intelligent. Cela ouvre de nouvelles possibilités dans des domaines comme le secours, l’agriculture ou la surveillance environnementale.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques veulent affiner ces principes biologiques et tester les essaims de robots dans des situations réelles. L’objectif est de créer des systèmes robotiques capables de s’auto-organiser et d’accomplir des tâches complexes aux côtés des humains.

**Message clé**
En apprenant des stratégies naturelles de coopération, les robots deviennent des collaborateurs plus intelligents, prêts à nous aider de nombreuses façons importantes.
articles.personality_title_es: Los robots aprenden trabajo en equipo de la biología para colaborar mejor
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han estado estudiando cómo los robots pueden trabajar juntos en grupos, llamados enjambres, para resolver problemas de forma más eficiente. Encontraron inspiración en la biología del desarrollo, el estudio de cómo crecen y se desarrollan los seres vivos, para mejorar el trabajo en equipo de los robots.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores aplicaron lecciones sobre cómo las células se comunican y se organizan durante el crecimiento para guiar a enjambres de robots. Al imitar estos procesos naturales, los robots pudieron coordinar mejor sus acciones y adaptarse sin control central.

**Impacto**
Este avance significa que los equipos de robots ahora pueden trabajar más eficazmente como grupo, mostrando un comportamiento colectivo más inteligente. Abre nuevas posibilidades en campos como búsqueda y rescate, agricultura o monitoreo ambiental.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean perfeccionar estos principios biológicos y probar los enjambres de robots en situaciones reales. El objetivo es crear sistemas robóticos que puedan autoorganizarse y realizar tareas complejas junto a los humanos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Al aprender de las estrategias naturales de trabajo en equipo, los robots se están convirtiendo en colaboradores más inteligentes, listos para ayudarnos de muchas maneras importantes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a group of small, friendly robots working together in harmony, interconnected by glowing lines symbolizing collective intelligence, set against a soft, natural background with gentle earth tones and simple shapes, emphasizing cooperation and shared purpose without any human figures.
